definition.name: RCVM2
definition.overview:
The Recreational Compiler Virtual Machine is stack-based. RCVM is not a pure stack machine, in that variables can be indexed into the stack. The stack is used for temporary storage and mostly removes the need for registers.

With V2 of the VM, changes include:

  • One stack.
  • Changes in call sequence (CALL vs GOSUB)
  • ability to reserve space for locals (RESERVE)
  • ability to access variables [local, parameters, return value] on stack (VLOAD, VSTORE)
  • VLOAD/VSTORE with negative value goes before frame (local variables), negative values are after frame (parameters and return value). NOTE: these are two different starting addresses -- if a frame is 6 bytes, negative values are from before byte #1 and positive values (including zero) are from after byte #6.
  • current CALL is renamed NCALL for NATIVE call
  • NATIVE call needs to be enhanced to allow storing of A/X/Y registers on stack
  • RETURN handles call sequence. Note that RETURN must be careful when restoring SP.
  • Push zeroes onto the stack (PUSHZ) to initialize up to 256 bytes of stack.
  • CALL handles new calling sequence (PC/SP/FP/BP/LP). Note that CALL must be careful when storing SP.
  • Removed IFEQ/IFNE/IFLT/IFLE/IFGT/IFGE and replaced with EQ/NE/LT/LE/GT/GE and an IFTRUE/IFFALSE.
  • Removed IFPLUS/IFMINUS.

Implementation changes in V2 of the interpreter:

  • Break apart source into multiple files.
  • Add bit 0 (push WORK1) to control structure.
  • Write specific routines for pushing WORK0 and WORK1 (should be a little faster).

address-mode.title: 8-bit value
address-mode.description: Instruction includes an 8-bit value which may be used for a count value or as a constant to be loaded onto the stack.

address-mode.title: 16-bit address or value
address-mode.description: Instruction includes a 16-bit address or value which is used for a branch target or as a constant to be loaded onto the stack.

address-mode.title: 32-bit value
address-mode.description: Instruction includes a 32-bit constant value which is loaded onto the stack.

address-mode.title: Floating point value
address-mode.description: Instruction includes a floating point value. Currently hard-wired at 40 bits based on Apple II interpreter.

address-mode.title: Native Call operation
address-mode.description: NCALL (Native Call) has its own specific address mode.

address-mode.title: Integer/Floating point instruction with 8-bit offset
address-mode.description: An instruction that both supports integer data types (8, 16, 32) and floating point stack operations. An 8-bit offset is included for branching.

address-mode.title: Integer/Floating point instruction with 16-bit address
address-mode.description: An instruction that both supports integer data types (8, 16, 32) and floating point stack operations. A 16-bit address follows that indicates the address impacted.

address-mode.title: Integer/Floating point instruction
address-mode.description: An instruction that both supports integer data types (8, 16, 32) and floating point stack operations.

address-mode.title: Two Integer/Floating point instruction
address-mode.description: An instruction that both supports TWO integer data types (8, 16, 32) or floating point stack operations.

address-mode.title: Integer-only instruction
address-mode.description: An instruction that both supports only integer data types (8, 16, 32).

address-mode.title: Integer point instruction with 16-bit address
address-mode.description: An instruction that supports integer data types (8, 16, 32). A 16-bit address follows that indicates the address impacted.

operation.description: Shut down VM.
Goto the specified address.
Call subroutine at addr, parameters on stack. Pushes SP, FP, PC onto stack
Return from subroutine, any return value left on stack. Restores SP, FP, PC from stack

Call native subroutine at physical address addr. Control byte identifies processor-specific information. For 6502/65C02:
  • 7 - Pop Acc. from stack
  • 6 - Pop X register from stack
  • 5 - Pop Y register from stack
  • 4 - Push Acc. onto stack
  • 3 - Push X register onto stack
  • 2 - Push Y register onto stack
  • 1 - undefined
  • 0 - undefined
Reserves n bytes of local space on stack.
( -- 0... ) Push zeroes onto the stack.
( a -- ) If a is true (non-zero) goto address.
( a -- ) If a is false (zero) goto address.
( -- n ) Load a value from physical memory.
( n -- ) Store a value to physical memory.
( n -- ) Drop a value from the stack.
( a b -- b a ) Swap the top two values on the stack.
( a b -- c ) Add the top two numbers
( a b -- c ) Subtract the top two numbers
( a b -- c ) Signed multiplication of the top two numbers.
( a b -- c ) Signed division of the top two numbers.
( a b -- c ) Signed modulus of the top two numbers.
( a b -- c ) Unsigned multiplication of the top two numbers. Does not include float.
( a b -- c ) Unsigned division of the top two numbers. Does not include float.
( a b -- c ) Unsigned modulus of the top two numbers.
( a -- a+1 ) Increment by one.
( a -- a-1 ) Decrement by one.
( a -- -a ) (Signed) Negate number.
( a b -- tf ) a == b
( a b -- tf ) a <> b
( a b -- tf ) a < b
( a b -- tf ) a <= b
( a b -- tf ) a > b
( a b -- tf ) a >= b

( n addr -- ) Store a value to physical memory using address on stack.
( a b -- c ) Bit-wise OR
( a b -- c ) Bit-wise AND
( a b -- c ) Bit-wise exclusive-OR
( a -- a' ) Shift bits left

( n -- n-1 ) Decrement TOS by 1, branch to address if not zero.

( a b -- mod div ) Unsigned division and modulus of the top two numbers.

Convert number from type "a" to type "b".
  • signed conversion a ⇔ b
  • sign extension: 1>2, 1>4, 2>4
  • truncation: 2>1, 4>2, 4>1
  • signed to float: 1>F, 2>F, 4>F
  • float to signed: F>1, F>2, F>4
  • unsigned to signed: 1>1, 2>2, 4>4
  • undefined: F>F

Convert number from type "a" to type "b".
  • unsigned conversion a ⇔ b
  • zero extension: 1>2, 1>4, 2>4
  • truncation: 2>1, 4>2, 4>1
  • unsigned to float: 1>F, 2>F, 4>F
  • float to unsigned: F>1, F>2, F>4
  • signed to unsigned: 1>1, 2>2, 4>4
  • undefined: F>F
( -- n ) Load variable value onto stack.
( n -- ) Store value from stack into variable space.
